The study also found that the percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively unchanged over time, despite the increases in heavy drinking. The study highlights cultural and economic explanations for the increase in excessive drinking, including changed social norms, increased affluence, and weakened alcohol control policies.

Marcus stayed calm throughout the 11-minute call and provided the dispatcher with instructions on how to reach them, including directions to "go up the steps right in the back hallways" and "it's a black door to the right." Prince George's County firefighters were able to enter the room by going through the home and breaking a window, and rescued Marcus and Aaliyah. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while their mother, step-father, and older brother escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

A fire broke out at the Sandpiper complex in Westhampton Beach, New York, on Wednesday at 3 pm, destroying 90 condos and causing the building to collapse. The fire was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings, and smoke could be seen from three miles away. Twelve fire teams were deployed, but they were unable to get inside the building. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, but it is believed to have started near a car parked by the complex. The building manager, Rob Taber, who lived and worked in the complex, said he has lost everything. The Sandpiper complex is used as a holiday home by residents between May and November.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer, gave a TED talk about embracing the word "fat" as a positive description of her body. She believes that the word doesn't have to be a synonym for "ugly" and that beauty comes in all shapes and sizes. Despite the fact that size discrimination has risen in the workplace, Lillian hopes that exposing her audience to a "fat" body in a positive and glamorous way will change their perceptions. She also recommends that people find a "courage reference" - a moment they felt brave that they can think back to at times when they feel insecure and afraid. The response to her talk has been mostly positive, with many people thanking her for her message and sharing their own personal stories.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw has been declared cancer-free after a long battle with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive form of childhood cancer. Harley was diagnosed with cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, but he remained brave throughout his treatment, even decorating his protective mask with a ninja turtle design. He underwent 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumor, and a stem cell transplant. After weeks of radiotherapy, Harley was finally given the all-clear by doctors. His story has inspired many, and he has become the face of Cancer Research UK's Kids and Teens campaign.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has been accused by Seminole County Elementary teachers of threatening to suspend her 5-year-old autistic son, Logan, for wearing essential oils to help combat his illness. The teachers claim that the oils smell and are a distraction to other students. Kemp argues that the oils, manufactured by doTERRA, help keep Logan calm and focused. Despite the threat of punishment, Kemp plans to continue fighting the decision and using the oils, which she believes have a positive impact on her son. The school district has since stated that they will not suspend Logan, citing it as a "health issue."

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, caused a fatal car crash in December 2013 that killed a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. Dellinger, who has pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault, faces 12 to 24 years in prison. The crash occurred when Dellinger, who was driving a pickup truck, crossed a median and collided with an oncoming SUV, killing the couple instantly. Dellinger's attorneys have claimed that he was suffering from Ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, and multiple sclerosis symptoms at the time of the crash. The prosecution argues that Dellinger had argued with his wife over his medications that morning and was driving recklessly. Dellinger's wife, Deborah, described her husband as a man of ethics, integrity, and friendship who has lived his life with grace and modesty despite his health problems. The victims' families have filed a wrongful death lawsuit against Dellinger.

A lost iPhone was reunited with its owner, Bella Crooke, after police posted a series of humorous photos and messages on her Facebook page in an attempt to track her down. The phone was handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border, and officers realized it was unlocked and used it to post selfies and puns on Bella's Facebook page. The posts included a photo of the phone in a holding cell and reassurances that it was in safe hands. Bella eventually reclaimed her phone, and she was recognized by officers who had seen her Facebook page. She was grateful for the police's good humor and has since put a password on her phone.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "Livin' la Vida Loca" music video, was hospitalized after collapsing due to low blood pressure. Italian media reported that she had attempted suicide, but Moric denied these claims on Instagram, stating that she was recovering at home and had no intention of ending her life. She explained that she had fallen and hurt herself due to low blood pressure, and that her boyfriend was not present at the time of the accident. Moric's former husband, Fabrizio Corona, a paparazzi photographer, was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photographs.

A baby boy was found dead in a pond in Norfolk, England in 1988. The case was reopened in 2015 and DNA samples were taken from the baby's remains. The DNA was matched to a possible relative of one of the parents, and police were able to identify the mother. The woman, who has not been named, was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but was later released on bail. She explained that she had concealed her pregnancy from her family and friends and had given birth to the baby by herself. The baby was stillborn, and the woman placed his body in the pond. Police have ruled out any foul play and the case has been closed. The baby was reburied in the churchyard of St Peter's Church in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, and has been named Peter.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built their own home using a 1986 Hino flatbed truck as the base. They purchased the truck and spent a year and a half building the home, which is now a two-bedroom, wood and steel structure that is powered mostly by solar panels. The home is surrounded by nature and features a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and other creature comforts. The couple plans to build another home like this in the future. The project cost them around $25,000.

A newborn baby named Star was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, and needed a transplant to survive. Her parents were not suitable matches, but her maternal aunt, Shanell, proved to be an ideal candidate and donated part of her liver to save Star's life. The transplant was successful, and Star has made a good recovery. She will need to take anti-rejection medication for the rest of her life and have regular blood tests and liver function tests. Shanell, Star's aunt and donor, said she didn't hesitate to step forward to save her niece's life.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured during the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana when he was struck by a car that had come in for tires and fuel. The car, driven by Francesco Dracone, spun out and clipped Phillips' leg, causing him to receive stitches for a cut. Two French tourists allegedly tried to set a quokka on fire on Rottnest Island in Western Australia. The quokka survived but was singed by the flame. They have been charged with animal cruelty and will appear in court on April 17. Quokkas are small animals, about the size of a domestic cat, and can be found on some small islands off the West Australian coast, including Rottnest Island and Bald Island.

A juvenile female Omura's whale was found washed up on a remote beach in Western Australia, the first sighting of the species in the state and only the second in the country. The species was previously thought to be extinct. The whale was identified using DNA profiling and its discovery is considered highly significant for scientists as very little is known about the species. The Omura's whale is found in tropical and subtropical waters, including Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. It has a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried and the skeleton will be recovered in a few years for further scientific investigation and possible public display in museums.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who was left with severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving taxi. Hicks had gotten into the taxi with his girlfriend at a rank in Bath, but Young, a former soldier, mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to "do a runner" and drove him back to the rank instead of taking him home. Hicks objected and jumped out of the taxi while it was moving at over 20mph, suffering devastating brain injuries as a result. The family of Hicks, who now requires round-the-clock care from his mother, took Young to the High Court, where a judge ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks and was therefore entitled to damages. A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, has been put up for sale for £575,000, but there's a catch. The passage discusses the wide leg trouser trend for Spring/Summer 2015, highlighting its appeal and versatility. A 44-year-old woman, Michelle Filkins, was arrested for breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property after she was found sitting in a summer home in Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard, that did not belong to her. Police are asking anyone who received items from the home, including a lamp and a painting, to return them to the Edgartown Police Department, as they are considered victims and will be eligible for restitution through the court prosecution. Anyone with information can contact the police department at 508-627-4343.

Blue fluorescent algae have been spotted lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. The phenomenon is caused by millions of plankton emitting light, creating a neon glow that illuminates the popular beaches. According to oceanography expert Iain Suthers, the algae is called Noctiluca scintillans and it blossoms in the spring and autumn due to natural causes, preying on another type of algae called diatoms and emitting the luminous glow as a defense mechanism. Similar displays have been seen in other parts of Australia, such as Manly Beach in Sydney back in 2014.

A 55-year-old man, Leon Yeaman, was killed by a single punch from his 28-year-old neighbor, Phillip Pama, during an argument over noise levels in front of their homes in North Brisbane. Pama, a married father of three, works a 3 am shift at a nearby warehouse and was sleeping at the time Yeaman was making a commotion. Pama's defense lawyer, Bruce Peters, said that Yeaman was known for getting drunk, playing loud music, and yelling at the world at large. Pama confronted Yeaman, and the situation escalated, resulting in Pama hitting Yeaman with a punch that killed him. Paramedics were unable to revive Yeaman, who was pronounced dead at the scene. Pama was charged with manslaughter and granted bail with conditions, including surrendering his passport, adhering to a curfew, and reporting to the local police station twice a week. The case is due to return to court on May 18.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old man with a history of criminal activity, attempted to rob a store in County Durham, England. He entered the store masked and wielding an axe, demanding cash from the terrified assistant. However, he was foiled by the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, who rugby tackled him to the floor, and his wife, Sam, who hit him twice with a baseball bat, causing him to drop the axe. McKerry was arrested and later jailed for six years. He had earned the nicknames "Boomerang Boy" and "Homing Pigeon Boy" due to his tendency to always return home after committing a crime.

Carlos Toro, a former member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for the promise of US citizenship. However, after he retired due to declining health, the DEA refused to help him with his citizenship, and he is now facing deportation. Toro helped the DEA carry out undercover stings around the world and was a key asset in the prosecution of several high-profile drug traffickers, including Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his contributions, Toro is now living in the US illegally and is afraid that if he is sent back to Colombia, he will be killed within the first four hours. His former handler, DEA agent Mike McManus, has spoken out in support of Toro, calling the government's treatment of him "bureaucracy at its worst." Toro remains in limbo, trying to secure a green card or passport, and is unable to collect social security benefits until he obtains one of these documents.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested in Washington D.C. for attempted burglary and destruction of property. He was arrested on a residential street in southeastern D.C. by the Metropolitan Police Department. The agency revoked his security clearance and put him on leave following the arrest. Baldwin was posted to the Foreign Missions Branch, which works with the State Department. He was to be arraigned Friday afternoon, but court records do not list an attorney for him. This arrest comes two days after a high-ranking supervisor was put on leave due to allegations of misconduct, which is also being investigated by police. The Homeland Security Department's Inspector General is investigating both incidents, which are the latest controversies for the agency responsible for protecting the president and his family.

Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after she struck her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar when she found her getting high on heroin in her bathroom. The passage discusses the benefits of oophorectomy (removal of ovaries) for women who carry the BRCA1 gene mutation and have been diagnosed with breast cancer. According to a study of 676 breast cancer patients with the mutated gene, oophorectomy was associated with a significant reduction in breast cancer deaths (62%) and overall mortality (65%) in women with the BRCA1 mutation. The study found that the protective effect of oophorectomy lasted for 15 years and was particularly effective for women with oestrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. The authors suggest that oophorectomy should be considered as part of the initial treatment for BRCA1 mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer.
